{{multiple| {{external links|date=April 2017}} {{refimprove|date=February 2011}} {{US-centric|date=November 2016}} }} '''Science outreach''', also called '''Education and Public Outreach''' ('''EPO''' or '''E/PO''') or simply '''public outreach''',{{citation needed|date=October 2015}} is an [[umbrella term]] for a variety of activities by [[research institute]]s, [[University|universities]], and institutions such as [[science museum]]s, aimed at promoting [[Public awareness of science|public awareness (and understanding) of science]] and making informal contributions to [[science education]].<ref>{{cite journal|author=Varner, Johanna|title=Scientific outreach: toward effective public engagement with biological science|journal=BioScience|volume=64|issue=4|year=2014|pages=333–340|doi=10.1093/biosci/biu021}}</ref>
==Scope and history==
While there have always been individual scientists interested in educating the public, science outreach has recently become more organized. For example, the National Aeronautics and Space Administration ([[NASA]]) now requires all of its projects to organize suitable outreach activities.{{Citation needed|date=April 2007}} Also working to inform the public are organizations such as Communicating Astronomy to the Public<ref>[http://www.communicatingastronomy.org/meetings/ Communicating Astronomy to the Public]</ref> and the Washington Declaration on Communicating Astronomy to the Public<ref>[http://www.nrao.edu/ccap/conf_wash.shtml Washington Declaration on Communicating Astronomy to the Public]</ref> that organize conferences for the public on science issues and make efforts to put outreach on a more general institutional footing.
Recently, an increasing number of projects have hired designated outreach scientists (part-time or full-time) that handle public relations for their project. There are also specialized outreach providers such as the Education branch of the [[Space Science Institute]]<ref>[http://www.spacescience.org/education/index.html Education branch of the Space Science Institute]</ref> in Boulder, Colorado and the [[NASA Education and Public Outreach Group at Sonoma State University|Education and Public Outreach Group]] at [[Sonoma State University]] which offer to organize a project's outreach activities on a contractual basis.
In addition to outreach by research institutions, an important part of informal science education are outreach programs such as [[science museum]]s and [[science festival]]s.
==Examples of science outreach activities==
Science outreach can take on a variety of forms.
===Public talks/lectures/discussions=== [[File:Universum für Alle - New book showcases ESO images.jpg|thumb|Universum für Alle: 70 short popular lectures at [[Heidelberg University]].<ref>{{cite news|title=New Book Showcases ESO Images|url=http://www.eso.org/public/announcements/ann12091/|accessdate=3 December 2012|newspaper=ESO Announcements}}</ref> ]]
Lectures are probably the oldest form of science outreach, dating back to the 1820s when [[Michael Faraday]] organized the first of the [[Royal Institution|Royal Institution's]] [[Royal Institution Christmas Lectures|Christmas Lectures]].<ref>{{cite web | title=The RI Christmas Lectures (Royal Institution Website)| url=http://www.rigb.org/rimain/events/christmaslectures.jsp}}</ref>
Public talks can be part of a lecture series, given at a [[science festival]] or in cooperation with a special interest group such as a local [[astronomy club]]. Public presentations can have a variety of formats, including straightforward lecture formats with or without [[Scientific demonstration|experimental demonstrations]], guided live interviews, and discussions with several participants and a moderator. There are also less formal initiatives such as [[Café Scientifique]], in which a café or bar is the venue for regular meetings involving guest scientists that come to talk about their work or take part in discussions with members of the public.
===Visiting primary and secondary schools===
School students and teachers are an important target group for science outreach. Outreach activities can include scientists visiting schools, giving talks at assemblies, discussions with students, or participation in events such as [[career fair]]s and science and technology camps. One organization that focuses on this kind of science outreach is [[Robogals]]. Many universities also have science outreach programs that are dedicated to building relationships between high school students, university scientists, and K-12 teachers. A few of the most prominent university science outreach programs include Carolina Science Outreach,<ref>{{cite web | title=Carolina Science Outreach | url=http://www.csousc.org}}</ref> the Vanderbilt Student Volunteers for Science,<ref>{{cite web | title=Vanderbilt Student Volunteers for Science | url=http://studentorgs.vanderbilt.edu/vsvs/}}</ref> the Rockefeller University Science Outreach Program,<ref>{{cite web | title=Rockefeller University Science Outreach Program | url=http://www.rockefeller.edu/outreach/}}</ref> the Present Your Ph.D. Thesis to a 12-Year Old Outreach Project at University of Texas in Austin,<ref>{{cite web | title=Science Educational Outreach Programs That Benefit Students and Scientists | url=http://journals.plos.org/plosbiology/article?id=10.1371/journal.pbio.1002368}}</ref> and the Stanford University Office of Science Outreach.<ref>{{cite web | title=Stanford University Office of Science Outreach| url=http://oso.stanford.edu/}}</ref> Using Canada as an example, it has been estimated that with sufficient organization, every classroom from kindergarten through graduation could in practice receive a visit from one or more scientists annually with participation from only 10-15% of the scientific enterprise.<ref>Bechara J. Saab, [http://www.hypothesisjournal.com/?p=902 "Engaging the Clutch of the Science Communication Continuum – Shifting Science Outreach into High Gear"], ''Hypothesis'' Volume 8 Issue 1 (September 2010).</ref> Some examples of science outreach programs in Canada include: [[Let's Talk Science]], [[Actua (Canadian charity)|Actua]], [[Chemical Institute of Canada|The Chemical Institute of Canada]], and [[Science Rendezvous]].
===Workshops/schools for teachers and/or students=== [[File:Cover of the ALMA radioastronomy manual.jpg|thumb|Cover of the [[Atacama Large Millimeter Array|ALMA]] [[radioastronomy]] manual.<ref>{{cite web|title=ALMA Material for Teachers|url=http://www.eso.org/public/announcements/ann15052/|accessdate=7 July 2015}}</ref>]] Inviting groups of school students to a research institution for a workshop is another popular form of outreach. Formats range from a one-day visit to more involved week-long events such as [[Perimeter Institute]]'s International Summer School for Young Physicists, a two-week-long programs for a total of a hundred Canadian and international students from grade 11.<ref>[http://www.perimeterinstitute.ca/Outreach/Education/ISSYP_Overview International Summer School for Young Physicists]</ref>
Another method of science outreach invites school teachers to participate in workshops where they are able to learn effective strategies to engage students in science. This approach was especially embraced by the [[Canadian Space Agency]] which held an annual "Space Educators" conference up until 2012 to provides teachers with access to resources to educate their students in space-related science.<ref>{{cite web | title=Canadian Space Agency Educators Resources | url=http://www.asc-csa.gc.ca/eng/educators/default.asp}}</ref>
===Supporting science fairs and similar events=== [[File:Cloud chamber as science for general public.jpg|thumb|One of the major goals of [[science festival]]s is to make [[science]] more accessible to [[general public]]. [[Cloud chamber]]s are popular at [[science fair]]s for their ability to visualize otherwise [[invisible]] [[radiation]] that surrounds us.]] Besides organizing independent events, many outreach organizations sponsor existing events that promote sciences awareness. A notable examples are [[science fair]]s, [[public science]] events in which working scientists can participate both as judges and as sponsors of student projects.
=== Online aggregation of science activities, resources, and programs === The internet is a rich source of science activities, resources, and programs. For example, research laboratories often maintain educational outreach projects aimed at translating their science into something meaningful for the general public, often [[K–12|K-12]] students, as an effort to increase research broader impacts required by funding agencies such as the NSF.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.nsf.gov/od/oia/special/broaderimpacts/|title=Broader Impacts - National Science Foundation|website=www.nsf.gov|access-date=2016-07-11}}</ref> These may include activities using fast-growing plants that exhibit distinctive mutants with unique [[phenotype]]s useful to teach K-12 students about both Mendelian and molecular genetics.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://fpsc.wisc.edu/program/index.shtm|title=FPsc: genetics, evolution, modern genetic sciences|website=fpsc.wisc.edu|access-date=2016-07-11}}</ref> Some institutions and organizations maintain large<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://science.wisc.edu/|title=Home {{!}} science.wisc.edu {{!}} University of Wisconsin–Madison|website=science.wisc.edu|access-date=2016-07-11}}</ref> or small<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.sanfordlab.org/education/updates|title=Education and Outreach {{!}} Sanford Underground Research Facility|website=www.sanfordlab.org|access-date=2016-07-11}}</ref> aggregations of their activity resources,<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.sanfordlab.org/education/curriculum-modules|title=Curriculum Modules {{!}} Sanford Underground Research Facility|website=www.sanfordlab.org|access-date=2016-07-11}}</ref> outreach programs,<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://science.wisc.edu/outreachprograms.htm|title=Outreach Programs {{!}} science.wisc.edu {{!}} University of Wisconsin–Madison|website=science.wisc.edu|access-date=2016-07-11}}</ref> upcoming events calendars,<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://today.wisc.edu/events/feed/2/|title=Science / UW-Madison Events Calendar|website=today.wisc.edu|access-date=2016-07-11}}</ref> and partnering programs.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://science.wisc.edu/sciencealliance.htm|title=Science Alliance {{!}} science.wisc.edu {{!}} University of Wisconsin–Madison|website=science.wisc.edu|access-date=2016-07-11}}</ref>
==Awards==
A number of awards honor commitment to science outreach. Examples include: * Award for Public Understanding of Science and Technology, [[American Association for the Advancement of Science]]<ref>[http://www.aaas.org/aboutaaas/awards/public/index.shtml Award for Public Understanding of Science and Technology], American Association for the Advancement of Science</ref> * Descartes Prize for Excellence in Science Communication, [[European Commission]]<ref>[http://cordis.europa.eu/science-society/descartes/home.html Descartes Prize for Excellence in Science Communication]</ref> * [[Michael Faraday Prize]] for communicating science to a [[United Kingdom|UK]] audience ([[Royal Society]]) * Communicator award, [[Deutsche Forschungsgemeinschaft]]<ref>[http://www.dfg.de/en/research_funding/scientific_prizes/communicator_award.html Communicator award], Deutsche Forschungsgemeinschaft</ref> * Synapse Mentorship Awards, often given for exceptional contributions to science outreach, [[Canadian Institutes of Health Research]]<ref>[http://www.cihr-irsc.gc.ca/e/32408.html Synapse Mentorship Awards]</ref> * Nicholson Medal for Human Outreach, [[American Physical Society]]<ref>[http://www.aps.org/programs/honors/awards/nicholson.cfm Nicholson Medal for Human Outreach]</ref> *[[Charles A. Black Award]], for exemplary contributions to public understanding of food and agricultural science * [[Kalinga Prize]] for popularisation of science is an award given by [[UNESCO]] since 1952 for exceptional skill in presenting scientific ideas to lay people
==See also== *[[List of Astronomy Outreach Resources in Europe]] *[[Science museum]] *[[Science festival]] *[[Popular science]] *[[Public science]] *[[Physics Outreach]] *[[Scientific literacy]]

Where is it held?}} {{Cleanup-PR|date=August 2018}} The '''September 11 National Day of Service and Remembrance''' or '''9/11 Day''' is a federally-recognized day of unity and charitable service, annually observed throughout the United States and in other countries around the world on the anniversary of the [[September 11 terrorist attacks]]. It has grown to become the largest annual day of charitable service in the United States.
==Background==
According to the nonprofit MyGoodDeed, which founded the September 11 National Day of Service and Remembrance ("9/11 Day") in 2002, the goal of "9/11 Day" is "to keep alive the spirit of unity and compassion that arose in the immediate aftermath of the [[September 11 attacks]] in tribute to the individuals lost and injured in the attacks, and the many who rose in service in response." The idea of making September 11 an annual day of service was first conceived in the winter of 2001 by David Paine, a former marketing executive from New York City. In the Spring of 2002 David was joined by his friend Jay Winuk, who had lost his brother Glenn Winuk in the attacks at the World Trade Center, and together they formed the nonprofit group called One Day's Pay. In 2007, the name of the organization was officially changed to MyGoodDeed. In 2009, MyGoodDeed successfully led an effort to designate September 11 under federal law as a National Day of Service and Remembrance, which occurred as part of passage of the bipartisan Edward M. Kennedy Serve America Act by the [[United States Congress]], and later, by an amendment to the Patriot Day [[Presidential Proclamation]] by President Barack Obama, which formally recognized and established September 11 as a National Day of Service and Remembrance. The Edward M. Kennedy Serve America Act authorized the Corporation for National and Community Service (CNCS), a federal agency, to assist the 9/11 community in building awareness of and support for "9/11 Day" through its national service programs. In 2011, on the 10th anniversary of the September 11 attacks, MyGoodDeed, CNCS and the Points of Light Institute/HandsOn Network joined together to organize the largest day of charitable service in U.S. history, with more than 32 million Americans participating, according to research conducted by Horizon Consumer Science on behalf of MyGoodDeed. Today, 9/11 Day continues to engage nearly 30 million Americans annually in various forms of charitable service, including volunteering, donations to charities, and simple good deeds.<ref>[https://911day.org/about/ About Us], 911day.org, published by MyGoodDeed, accessed July 20, 2016</ref><ref>[http://www.serve.gov/?q=site-page/september-11th-national-day-service-and-remembrance|September 11th National Day of Service and Remembrance], serve.gov, published by the Corporation for National and Community Service, accessed July 20, 2016</ref><ref>[http://www.pointsoflight.org/signature-events/911-day-service-and-remembrance/2011|9/11 Day of Service and Remembrance 2011], pointsoflight.org, published by the Points of Light Foundation, accessed July 20, 2016</ref>
==Activities==
Activities by volunteers on this federally-recognized National Day of Service and Remembrance happen all across the nation, and include lesson plans that engage tens of thousands of students of all ages in service activities; coast-to-coast blood drives; meal packing projects; painting and refurbishing homes; food drives; reclaiming neighborhoods; helping communities prepare for disasters; and countless other activities that support and honor those lost and injured on 9/11; veterans, soldiers, military families, and rescue and recovery workers, including first responders. Among the largest projects held annually are two large-scale hunger relief projects, one in New York City and another at the National Mall in Washington, DC, which mobilize a total of more than 7,000 volunteers who together pack over two million meals for individuals at risk of hunger. In Boston, thousands join together on 9/11 at the Rose Kennedy Greenway to assemble care packages for military personnel. Participants are encouraged to use the [[hashtag]] #911Day when posting online about the day.<ref>[http://www.serve.gov/?q=site-page/september-11th-national-day-service-and-remembrance|September 11th National Day of Service and Remembrance], serve.gov, published by the Corporation for National and Community Service, accessed July 20, 2016</ref><ref>[http://ysa.org/act/programs/911day/ 9/11 Day of Service & Remembrance], ysa.org, published by Youth Service America, accessed July 20, 2016</ref><ref>{{cite news|title=Volunteers Honor 9/11 Victims By Helping Others On National Day Of Service|url=http://newyork.cbslocal.com/2012/09/11/volunteers-honor-911-victims-by-helping-others-on-national-day-of-service/|accessdate=2 December 2012|newspaper=CBS New York|date=11 September 2012}}</ref>

{{Use dmy dates|date=July 2013}} [[File:Britney Europe.jpg|thumb|Rise in popularity of thongs among younger girls has been attributed to pop idols like [[Britney Spears]] and [[Jennifer Lopez]].<ref name="auto">[http://www.sfgate.com/cgi-bin/article.cgi?file=/chronicle/archive/2002/06/16/LV184497.DTL Grin and bare it], San Francisco Chronicles</ref> Picture shows Britney Spears performing, 2011.]] The '''social impact of thong underwear''' has been covered extensively in the media, ranging from a ban on wearing [[thong (clothing)|thong]]s to thongs for the underaged. The rise of thong usage has been asserted by Christian minister Oneil McQuick to be linked to a rise of [[sexualization]] in society,<ref>{{cite book|first=Oneil|last=McQuick|url=https://books.google.com/?id=Ewm93pO7YQcC&pg=PT1&dq=thong+society+sex|title=The Sexuality Series|page=29|publisher=L.I.M Publishing|year=2007|isbn=1-4196-4225-1}}</ref> and by Christian writer Philo Thelos to be linked to a rise in a desire to go unclothed.<ref>{{cite book|first=Philo|last=Thelos|url=https://books.google.com/?id=KpYJYeKiss8C&pg=PA52&dq=thong+society+sex|title=Divine Sex: Liberating Sex from Religious Tradition|page=52|publisher=Trafford Publishing|year=2003|isbn=1-55395-400-9}}</ref>
== Overview == [[File:Thong (cropped).jpg|thumb|Woman wearing a T-back thong in [[Sunrise, Florida]], USA in 2006]]
When discussing the trend of wearing thongs, Christian writer Sharon Daugherty comments in her book ''What Guys See That Girls Don't: Or Do They?'' that the fashion industry "may have changed the mindset of our society",<ref>{{cite book|first=Sharon|last=Daugherty|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=g3kx5Z42GPYC||title=What Guys See That Girls Don't: Or Do They?|page=61|publisher=Destiny Image Publishers|year=2006|isbn=0-7684-2368-6}}</ref> which was followed by the observation that "the whole idea of wearing so that no panty line or bumps can show isn't substantiated" and that "the thong was created by fashion designers to arouse sexual thoughts".{{sfn|Daugherty|2006|page=63}}
[[Monica Lewinsky]] gave evidence during the [[Lewinsky scandal]] that she was flirting with [[Bill Clinton]] in [[Leon Panetta]]'s office, and that she lifted her jacket to show him the straps of her thong underwear above her pants.<ref>{{cite web | last = Starr | first = Kenneth | author-link = Ken Starr | title = Report to the House on President Clinton: Narrative Pt. II: Initial Sexual Encounters (extract) | url = https://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-srv/politics/special/clinton/icreport/6narritii.htm | website = washingtonpost.com | publisher = [[The Washington Post]] | date = September 1998 }}</ref> Some of the news media in America used thong underwear as a metonym for smut in the [[Starr Report]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.slate.com/articles/news_and_politics/explainer/1998/09/the_thong_show.html|title=The Thong Show|date=22 September 1998|publisher=|via=Slate}}</ref> According to feminist commentator [[Carrie Lukas]], Lewinsky "with her thong-snapping seduction, forever changed the image of the D.C. junior staffer from aspiring policy wonk to sexual temptress."<ref>{{citation | last = Lukas | first = Carrie | author-link = Carrie Lukas | contribution = Sex: love's got something to do with it | editor-last = Lukas | editor-first = Carrie | editor-link = Carrie Lukas | title = The politically incorrect guide to women, sex, and feminism | page = 21 | publisher = Regency Publishing | location = Washington, DC Lanham, Maryland | year = 2006 | isbn = 9781596980037 | ref = harv | postscript = .}} [https://books.google.com/books?id=BVf_dCr023IC&pg=PA21&dq=thong+woman+sex&lr=&ei=sw4FSOahHIT6yATl3pj-Dw&sig=OCS8-3Pm9Npbe4q3ZRklqehUVzE#PPA21,M1 Preview.]</ref>
Marketing analysts Marian L. Salzman, Ira Matathia and Ann O'Reilly observed in the book ''Buzz: Harness the Power of Influence and Create Demand'' that thong brands are riding on the wide media coverage of thongs to create [[Word of mouth|buzz]].<ref>Marian L. Salzman, Ira Matathia and Ann O'Reilly, [https://books.google.com/books?id=sf85DYe9140C&pg=PA116&dq=thong+society+sex&lr=&ei=4vcESNDMF5jWyATNt_D9Dg&sig=f7ebSu-0y8UlAac7H8tqhsOIUiw Buzz: Harness the Power of Influence and Create Demand], Page 116, John Wiley and Sons, 2003, {{ISBN|0-471-27345-7}}</ref> Photographer [[Lauren Greenfield]] wrote in her book ''Girl Culture'', "Understanding the [[dialectic]] between the extreme and the mainstream – the anorexic and the dieter, the stripper and the teenager who bares her midriff or wears a thong – is essential to understanding contemporary feminine identity."<ref>Lauren Greenfield, [https://books.google.com/books?id=TUT9vKPr4_YC&pg=PT155&dq=thong+britney+spears&lr=&ei=TxEFSNTxLYOOywSSjuCiDw&sig=gCRLKGJiBIpHS_FdG9K02x9uk4k Girl Culture], Chronicle Books, 2002, {{ISBN|0-8118-3790-4}}</ref>
In 2004, political commentator Cedric Muhammad wrote in essay ''The Thong versus the Veil'', "We wondered at the end of the day, of the two groups of women most prominently featured on American TV these days, who gains more respect for their intellect and spirit – the Afghan woman who is so totally veiled that you can't even see her eyes or the Black woman in the R&B and Hip-Hop video who dances while wearing a bikini and thong?"<ref>Laura Flanders (ed.), [https://books.google.com/books?id=gg5NNztsUooC&pg=PA180&dq=thong+culutre+sex&lr=&ei=DhgFSLXXPJTAzATBy_yXDg&sig=QZNRmkA0_poI66Hywqj9tkkPYyg#PPA181,M1 The W Effect: Bush's War on Women], Page 181, Feminist Press, 2004, {{ISBN|1-55861-471-0}}</ref>
==School restrictions== The dress code for [[St. Ambrose Academy]], a Roman Catholic middle school and high school in [[Madison, Wisconsin]], specifically addresses swimsuits with "thong-cut legs" as inappropriate.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.ambroseacademy.org/dresscode.pdf |title=Ambrose Academy website |publisher=Ambroseacademy.org |accessdate=1 January 2012 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080727005219/http://www.ambroseacademy.org/dresscode.pdf |archivedate=27 July 2008 |df=dmy }}</ref> At [[Dixon High School (California)|Dixon High School]] in [[Dixon, California]], the dress code specifies that all undergarments – specifically listing thongs, along with [[bra]]s and [[briefs]] – must be covered.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://dhs.dixonusd.org/PAGES/Information/rules_dress.htm |title=Dixon High School |publisher=Dhs.dixonusd.org |date= |accessdate=2013-03-14 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20071011210154/http://dhs.dixonusd.org/PAGES/Information/rules_dress.htm |archivedate=11 October 2007 |df=dmy }}</ref> [[University of Victoria]] Law School briefly put the school logo on thongs, but quickly pulled them from sale after controversy sprung up.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.indissent.com/jan2003/lawnews.htm |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20030810135944/http://www.indissent.com/jan2003/lawnews.htm |archivedate=2003-08-10 |title=Indissent, University of Victoria |publisher=Web.archive.org |date=10 August 2003 |accessdate=1 January 2012}}</ref>
In 1999 a [[Miami University]] male professor was banned from using the school's recreation center because he refused to stop wearing thong swimwear. The professor challenged the school in court.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://enquirer.com/editions/1999/03/02/loc_professor_sues_miami.html|title= Professor sues Miami U to keep thong swimsuit |date=2 March 1999|accessdate=6 January 2016|publisher=[[Cincinnati Enquirer]]}}</ref> In 2000 a [[Salinas, California|Salinas]] High School principal was in the center of a variety of controversies including bans on clothing to the extent that "thong panties were unofficially banned." One student alleged that she was given a dress-code violation note for wearing a thong.<ref name="Monterey County Weekly" /><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.metroactive.com/papers/metro/12.14.00/dresscode-0050.html |title=Metro Active |publisher=Metro Active |date=14 September 2000 |accessdate=1 January 2012}}</ref> This story made national headlines in the United States.<ref name="Monterey County Weekly">[https://archive.is/20070628153120/http://www.montereycountyweekly.com/articles/7128/print Monterey County Weekly] </ref><ref>{{cite news|url=http://transcripts.cnn.com/TRANSCRIPTS/0009/13/tod.04.html |title=CNN transcript |publisher=Transcripts.cnn.com |date=13 September 2000 |accessdate=1 January 2012}}</ref>
In 2002, a female high school vice principal in San Diego physically checked up to 100 female students' underwear<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.10news.com/news/1515763/detail.html |title=Channel 10 news |publisher=10news.com |date=17 June 2002 |accessdate=1 January 2012 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20111120184346/http://www.10news.com/news/1515763/detail.html |archivedate=20 November 2011 |df=dmy }}</ref> as they entered the school for a dance, with or without student permission, causing an uproar among students and some parents and eliciting an investigation by the school into the vice principal's conduct.<ref>[http://www.nbcsandiego.com/News/1427309/detail.html NBC San Diego] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20071011160853/http://www.nbcsandiego.com/News/1427309/detail.html |date=11 October 2007 }}</ref> In her defense, the vice principal said the checks were for student safety and not specifically because of the wearing of thongs.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.signonsandiego.com/news/northcounty/20020605-9999_2m5thong.html |title=> News > North County - 2 on RB High staff faulted for checks of undergarments |publisher=SignOnSanDiego.com |date=2002-06-05 |accessdate=2013-03-14}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.signonsandiego.com/news/northcounty/20020616-9999_2m16thong.html |title=> News > North County - Demotion possible for assistant principal |publisher=SignOnSanDiego.com |date=2002-06-16 |accessdate=2013-03-14}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.usatoday.com/news/nation/2002/06/18/thong-demotion.htm |title=USA Today |work=USA Today |date=18 June 2002 |accessdate=1 January 2012}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.cbsnews.com/stories/2002/06/18/national/main512654.shtml |title=CBS News |publisher=CBS News |date=11 February 2009 |accessdate=1 January 2012}}</ref><ref>[http://www.nbcsandiego.com/News/1429777/detail.html NBC San Diego] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20071214172315/http://www.nbcsandiego.com/News/1429777/detail.html |date=14 December 2007 }}</ref> In 2003, the [[head teacher]] of a British primary school voiced her concern after learning that female students as young as 10 were wearing thong underwear to school. This incident led to a media debate about the appropriateness of thong underwear marketed to young girls.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/education/2943874.stm |title=Bbc (Uk) |publisher=BBC News |date=28 May 2003 |accessdate=1 January 2012}}</ref>
==Sports== The [[University of California]] [[4-H]] program specifically forbids "string, thong or crochet" swimsuits for women.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://ucce.ucdavis.edu/files/filelibrary/2557/28364.doc |title=University of California, Davis |accessdate=1 January 2012 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120208005132/http://ucce.ucdavis.edu/files/filelibrary/2557/28364.doc |archivedate=8 February 2012 |df=dmy }}</ref> For men, the dress code specifies "swim trunks only (no shorts, cut-off pants, or Speedos)." A similar policy by [[Virginia]] [[FCCLA]] bans "skimpy bikini or thong type suits" for women and specifies "swim trunks" for men ("no speedos").<ref>[http://www.me.vccs.edu/fccla/documents/DressCode_000.doc VCCS FCCLA website]{{dead link|date=January 2012}}</ref>
In 2001, [[Vicky Botwright]], then 16th seeded in women's squash circuit and dubbed the "Lancashire Hot Bot", was prohibited by the [[Women's International Squash Players Association]] (WISPA) from wearing a thong and a sports bra in the British Open Championships.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/low/other_sports/1408489.stm |title=All thong wrong @ BBC Sports Online |accessdate= |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20021203211540/http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/low/other_sports/1408489.stm |archivedate=3 December 2002 |df=dmy-all }}</ref>
In 2004, Alexander Putnam competed in the [[London Marathon]] in a green thong and painted as a tropical tree to protest against logging in Congo.<ref>[http://www.rainforestfoundationuk.org/s-%93Mara-thong%94%20Man%20runs%20from%20Congo%20loggers "Mara-thong" Man runs from Congo loggers], Rainforest Foundation</ref>
[[Female bodybuilder]]s in America are prohibited from wearing thong or T-back swimsuits if contests are being filmed for television, otherwise they are allowed to do so by certain fitness organizations.<ref>Maria R. Lowe, ''Women of steel: female bodybuilders and the struggle for self-definition'', page 191, New York University Press, 1998, {{ISBN|0-8147-5094-X}}</ref>
==Bans== In October 2002, Florida officials banned thongs from [[Daytona Beach, Florida|Daytona Beach]] and other public beaches.<ref>{{cite newspaper|url=https://www.usatoday.com/news/nation/2003-01-05-spring-break-usat_x.htm|title=Alcohol-soaked spring break lures students abroad|newspaper=USA Today|author=Donna Leinwand|date=2003-01-05}}</ref>
==Thongs for younger girls== The 2000s saw a rise in the popularity of thongs among younger girls, who have been dubbed "thong feminists" by comedian [[Janeane Garofalo]]. The trend has been attributed to pop idols like [[Britney Spears]] and [[Jennifer Lopez]].<ref name="auto"/> In 2002 [[Abercrombie & Fitch]] released a line of thong underwear targeted for girls ages 10–16, though critics pointed out that children as young as seven could fit one of the thongs.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://money.cnn.com/2002/05/22/news/companies/abercrombie/ |title=CNN Money |publisher=CNN |date=28 May 2002 |accessdate=1 January 2012}}</ref><ref name="JS Online">[http://www.jsonline.com/story/index.aspx?id=43941 JS Online] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20071114063620/http://www.jsonline.com/story/index.aspx?id=43941 |date=14 November 2007 }}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=https://query.nytimes.com/gst/fullpage.html?res=9E0DE3D9163BF937A15756C0A9649C8B63 |title=New York Times |work=New York Times |date=24 May 2002 |accessdate=1 January 2012 |first=Leslie |last=Kaufman}}</ref> A spokesman for A&F, Hampton Carney, stated that he could list "at least 100 reasons why a young girl would want thong underwear."<ref name="JS Online"/> This controversy spawned a great deal of free publicity for Abercrombie, including a chain letter that received wide circulation.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.breakthechain.org/exclusives/aandf.html |title=Break the Chain website |publisher=Breakthechain.org |date=6 June 2002 |accessdate=1 January 2012 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120122041435/http://www.breakthechain.org/exclusives/aandf.html |archivedate=22 January 2012 }}</ref> British retailer [[Argos (retailer)|Argos]] produced child-size thongs and padded [[Brassiere|bras]] for girls as young as nine, eliciting a similar response from the public.<ref>{{cite news|author=20 Feb 2007 |url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/main.jhtml?xml=/news/2007/02/20/ngirls220.xml |title=(UK) |publisher=The Telegraph |date=20 February 2007 |accessdate=1 January 2012 |location=London}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|author=This Is Money |url=http://www.dailymail.co.uk/pages/live/articles/news/news.html?in_article_id=363110&in_page_id=1770&in_a_source=&ito=1490 |title=(UK) |work=Daily Mail |location=UK |date=9 July 2001 |accessdate=1 January 2012}}</ref> [[Etam UK|Etam]], another British retailer, produced [[Sheer (textile)|sheer]] [[Top (clothing)|top]]s and thong underwear for girls of similar age.<ref>[http://www.thesun.co.uk/article/0,,2-2003140951,00.html The Sun (UK)]{{dead link|date=January 2012}}</ref> In Japan, photobooks and DVDs of underaged girls in T-back thongs has become popular as "T-back Junior Idols", which has come under scorn as a new form of child pornography.<ref>[http://search.japantimes.co.jp/cgi-bin/nn20070503f1.html Photos of preteen girls in thongs now big business], Japan Times</ref>
==Indecent exposure== * In August 2007 a man in Texas was arrested for [[indecent exposure]] for being naked in his own backyard. He reported that he was in fact wearing a thong and was not naked.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.sanmarcosrecord.com/local/local_story_220113341.html |title=San Marcos Daily Record "Backyard exposure leads to arrest" |publisher=Sanmarcosrecord.com |date=8 August 2007 |accessdate=1 January 2012 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090907090215/http://www.sanmarcosrecord.com/local/local_story_220113341.html |archivedate=7 September 2009 |df=dmy }}</ref>
==Other impacts== * A [[YMCA]] management firm has addressed thongs in dress code policy, stating (in different areas) that "thong-type wear isn't an issue." Additionally, an email from a university fitness center implied that there are safety issues ("thongs on bike seats") that would need to be addressed.<ref name="Monterey County Weekly"/> * In 2007 a man who had broken into a home wearing only a thong was sentenced to 20 years in prison for burglary and attempted rape.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.wcpo.com/news/local/story.aspx?content_id=c8cbbd15-6323-407c-a4c6-ce127acc23b3|title=WPCO 9 (ABC) "Thong-Wearing Burglar Sentenced"|publisher=|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20071215025154/http://www.wcpo.com/news/local/story.aspx?content_id=c8cbbd15-6323-407c-a4c6-ce127acc23b3|archivedate=15 December 2007|df=dmy-all}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.local12.com/news/local/story.aspx?content_id=310a577e-96c7-48fe-ba8c-6e3d857308c6 |title=WKRC 12 (CW) "Thong Robber Sentenced to Prison Time" |publisher=Local12.com |date=24 July 2007 |accessdate=1 January 2012 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080518091250/http://www.local12.com/news/local/story.aspx?content_id=310a577e-96c7-48fe-ba8c-6e3d857308c6 |archivedate=18 May 2008 |df=dmy }}</ref> He pleaded "guilty but mentally ill" at the May trial and was sentenced in July. * In 2007 the [[Tennessee]] Department of Correction banned prison visitors from wearing thong or g-string underwear. In the words of Correction Commissioner George Little, prisoners "don't need any help getting turned on."<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.foxnews.com/story/0,2933,290945,00.html |title=Fox News "Tennessee Bans Prison Visitors From Wearing G-Strings, Sexy Lingerie" |publisher=Fox News |accessdate=1 January 2012 |date=7 December 2011}}</ref> * After the [[2004 Indian Ocean earthquake|2004 Indian Ocean tsunami]], thousands of thongs were donated to relief organizations sending relief packages to [[Sri Lanka]]. These were largely discarded amongst the influx of more culturally sensitive and functional utilitarian clothing items. * During photography for [[Google Street View]], a woman in a thong was one of the images discovered that caused consternation over the project.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://news.seoreligion.com/google-street-view-showing-sunbathing-and-a-womans-thong.html |title=» Google Street View Showing Sunbathing and A Woman’s Thong » Blog Archive » SEO/SEM News |publisher=News.seoreligion.com |date=3 June 2007 |accessdate=1 January 2012 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20111220070543/http://news.seoreligion.com/google-street-view-showing-sunbathing-and-a-womans-thong.html |archive-date=20 December 2011 |dead-url=yes |df=dmy-all }}</ref> * In 2005, the [[Daily News (New York)|New York Daily News]] reported an incident of female United States military soldiers in Iraq stripping down to their thongs to participate in [[mud wrestling]] as an entertaining show.<ref>[http://www.nydailynews.com/archives/news/2005/02/06/2005-02-06_out_of_control_at_camp_crazy.html Female soldiers dress down & get dirty for mud romps G.I.S GONE WILD], NY Daily News {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080519003450/http://www.nydailynews.com/archives/news/2005/02/06/2005-02-06_out_of_control_at_camp_crazy.html |date=19 May 2008 }}</ref>
==Popular culture==
* In 2000, [[R&B]] singer [[Sisqó]] recorded the "[[Thong Song]]" on his ''[[Unleash the Dragon]]'' album. * Writer-director Glen Weiss made three movies titled the ''[[Thong Girl]]'', based on the comic book of the same name.<ref>{{cite web|author=Lloyd DeBerry |url=http://www.thonggirlfilms.com/ |title=Thong Girl |publisher=Thonggirlfilms.com |accessdate=1 January 2012}}</ref> The story of the films revolved around the Thong Girl, an independent [[superhero]]. Parts of the film were shot in [[Nashville, Tennessee|Nashville]]'s mayor's office in 2007.<ref>[http://www.indissent.com/jan2003/lawnews.htm In Dissent] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20071011172530/http://www.indissent.com/jan2003/lawnews.htm |date=11 October 2007 }}</ref> * Beermaker [[Rolling Rock]] aired a commercial poking fun of male thong wearers during [[Super Bowl|Super Bowl XLI]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.splendad.com/ads/show/443-Rolling-Rock-Man-Thong-Apology |title=SplendAD |publisher=SplendAD |accessdate=1 January 2012}}</ref> * [[Shefali Zariwala]], a model in [[India]], became known as the "thong girl" for her performance in the music video of the song ''Kaanta Laga''.<ref>[http://timesofindia.indiatimes.com/bangalore-times/im-indias-original-thong-girl/articleshow/1874777.cms 'I'm India's original thong girl'], Times of India</ref> The album sold two million copies and the music video became an overnight success in India.<ref>[http://www.abc.net.au/worldtoday/content/2003/s1013035.htm Indian Government censors music videos], Australian Broadcasting Corporation</ref> * In 2008, a diamond studded thong worth US$122,000 was featured in a Singapore lingerie fashion show. It had 518 brilliant-cut diamonds, totaling {{convert|30|carat|g}}, studded into the front of a black lace thong in a floral pattern, as well as 27 white gold tassels hanging off it.<ref>[http://in.reuters.com/article/oddlyEnoughNews/idINSIN13091520080403 Diamond thong shown to the throng] Reuters</ref>
==See also== {{Portal|Fashion|Sociology}} *[[Thong (clothing)]] *[[G-string]] *[[Whale tail]] *[[Sexual objectification]] *[[Sexual revolution]] *[[Underwear as outerwear]]

{{mergeto|social security|date=October 2018}} '''Social protection''', as defined by the [[United Nations Research Institute For Social Development]], is concerned with preventing, managing, and overcoming situations that adversely affect people’s [[well being]].<ref>United Nations Research Institute for Social Development (UNRISD). 2010. Combating [[Poverty]] and Inequality: Structural Change, Social Policy and Politics.</ref> Social protection consists of policies and programs designed to reduce [[poverty]] and vulnerability by promoting efficient [[labour market]]s, diminishing people's exposure to risks, and enhancing their capacity to manage economic and social risks, such as [[unemployment]], [[social exclusion|exclusion]], sickness, [[disability]] and old age.<ref>World Bank. 2001. Social Protection Sector Strategy Paper: From Safety Net to Springboard. Washington DC, USA.</ref>
The most common types of social protection:
*'''Labor market interventions''' are policies and programs designed to promote employment, the efficient operation of labor markets and the protection of workers. *'''[[Social insurance]]''' mitigates risks associated with unemployment, ill health, disability, work-related injury and old age, such as health insurance or unemployment insurance. *'''[[Social safety net|Social assistance]]''' is when resources, either cash or in-kind, are transferred to vulnerable individuals or households with no other means of adequate support, including single parents, the homeless, or the physically or mentally challenged.
==History of social protection== Traditionally, social protection has been used in the [[European welfare state]] and other parts of the developed world to maintain a certain living standard, and address transient poverty.<ref>United Nations Research Institute for Social Development (UNRISD). 2010. Combati ng Poverty and Inequality: Structural Change, Social Policy and Politics.</ref> One of the first examples of state-provided social protection can be tracked to the Roman Emperor [[Trajan]], who expanded a program for free grain to include more poor citizens of the empire. In addition, he instituted public funds to support poor children.<ref>Hammond, Mason. “Trajan”. Encyclopædia Britannica. http://www.britannica.com/EBchecked/topic/602150/Trajan#tab=active~checked%2Citems~checked&title=Trajan%20--%20Britannica%20Online%20Encyclopedia.</ref> Organized [[welfare]] was not common until the late 19th and early 20th centuries. It was during this period that in both Germany and Great Britain, welfare systems were established to target the working classes (see [[National Insurance]]).<ref>“The Liberal reforms 1906-1914”. BBC. http://www.bbc.co.uk/schools/gcsebitesize/history/mwh/britain/liberalreformsrev2.shtml</ref> The United States followed several years later, during the [[Great Depression]], with emergency relief for those struck the hardest. However, modern social protection has grown to envelop a much broader range of issues and purposes; it is now being used as a policy approach in developing nations, to address issues of persistent poverty and target structural causes. Moreover, it is designed to lift recipients out of poverty, rather than exclusively providing passive protection against contingencies .<ref name="auto">United Nations Research Institute for Social Development (UNRISD). 2010. Combating Poverty and Inequality: Structural Change, Social Policy and Politics.</ref> social protection has rapidly been used in trying to reduce and ultimately eliminate poverty and suffering in developing countries (mostly in Africa), so to enhance and promote economic and social growth.
==Types of social protection==
===Labor market Interventions=== Labor market interventions, consisting of both active and passive policies, provide protection for the poor who are capable of gaining employment. Passive programs, such as unemployment insurance, income support and changes in labor legislation, allieviate the financial needs of the unemployed but are not designed to improve their employability.<ref>Governance and Social Development Resource Centre. [Date accessed October 31, 2010] (http://www.gsdrc.org/go/topic-guides/social-protection/types-of-social-protection)</ref> A European Union-funded research as part of the DRIVERS project revealed a linear relationship between investments in national active labour market policies (specifically those directed towards integrating vulnerable groups into employment) and quality of work. It found that European countries with more active labour market policies seem to have healthier, less stressed workplaces.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://health-gradient.eu/lower-education-leads-to-a-more-stressful-working-life-labour-market-policies-can-mitigate-this/|title=Health Gradient - EuroHealthNet|website=health-gradient.eu}}</ref>
On the other hand, active programs focus on directly increasing the access of unemployed workers.<ref>Asian Development Bank. Labor. [Date accessed October 31, 2010] (http://www.adb.org/SocialProtection/labor.asp)</ref> [[Active labour market policies]] (ALMPs) are used to reduce the risk of unemployment and to increase the earnings capacity of workers. ALMPs have two basic objectives: (1) economic, by increasing the ability of the unemployed to find jobs, and increase productivity and earnings; and (2) social, by improving the inclusion and participation of productive employment. These programs have the ability to increase employment opportunities and address the social problems that often accompany high unemployment. Active policies are a way of reversing the negative effects of industrial restructuring in transition economies and to help integrate vulnerable people furthest from the labor markets.<ref>The World Bank. Social Protection. [Date accessed October 31, 2010] (http://web.worldbank.org/WBSITE/EXTERNAL/TOPICS/EXTSOCIALPROTECTION/ EXTLM/0,,contentMDK:20223809~menuPK:7109967~pagePK:148956~piPK:216618~theSitePK:390615,00.html)</ref> ALMPs are often targeted to the long-term unemployed, workers in poor families, and particular groups with labor market disadvantages. These programs have important social, as well as economic, objectives. Active labor market programs include a wide range of activities to stimulate employment and productivity such as: *'''Employment services.''' These services include counseling, placement assistance, job matching, labor exchanges, and other related services to improve the functioning of the labor market. *'''Job Training'''. This includes training/retraining for the unemployed, workers in mass layoffs and youth to increase the quantity of work supply. *'''Direct employment generation''' The promotion of small and medium enterprises (e.g., public works projects, subsidies) to increase labor demand.<ref>Betcherman, G., Olivas, K. and Dar, A., 2004, ‘Impacts of Active Labor Market Programs: New Evidence from Evaluations with Particular Attention to Developing and Transition Countries’, Social Protection Discussion Paper Series no. 0402, World Bank, Washington</ref> A common issue in implementing successful labor market interventions is how to incorporate the informal economy, which comprises a significant portion of the workforce in developing countries.<ref name="auto1">Governance and Social Development Resource Centre. [Date accessed October 31, 2010] (http://www.gsdrc.org/go/topic-guides/social protection/types-of-social-protection)</ref> Informal employment comprises between half and three quarters of non-agricultural employment in the majority of these countries. The proportion of informal employment increases when agriculture is taken into account.<ref>International Labour Organization. [Date accessed October 31, 2010] (http://www.ilo.org/public/english/protection/secsoc/areas/policy/informal.htm)</ref> Most informal workers are not covered by social security schemes, occupational safety and health measures, working conditions regulations and have limited access to health services and work-related measures of social protection. Labor market interventions work to integrate the different strategies to prevent and compensate occupational and social risks in the informal economy. The strategies that include measures to prevent and mitigate the impact of risks are the most effective.<ref>Lund, F., 2009, ‘Social Protection and the Informal Economy: Linkages and Good Practices for Poverty Reduction and Empowerment’, in Organisation for Economic Cooperation and Development (OECD), ‘Promoting Pro-Poor Growth: Social Protection’, OECD, Paris, pp.69-88</ref>
In general, public expenditure on labor market policy (LMP) interventions falls within three main categories: *'''Labor Market Services (1)''' *'''Total LMP Measures (2-7)''' training (2), job rotation & job sharing (3), employment incentives (4), supported employment & rehabilitation (5), direct job creation (6), start-up incentives (7),
*'''Total LMP supports (8-9)''' out-of-work income maintenance and support (8), early retirement (9)
===Social insurance=== {{Main|Social insurance}} Social insurance schemes are contributory programs that protect beneficiaries from catastrophic expenses in exchange for regular payments of premiums. Health costs can be very high, so health insurance schemes are a popular way reducing risk in the event of shock.<ref name="auto1"/> However, an individual with low income may not be able to afford insurance. Some argue that insurance schemes should be complemented with social assistance. Community-based health insurance allows pooling in settings where institutional capacity is too weak to organize nationwide risk-pooling, especially in low-income countries, making insurance more affordable. In risk-sharing schemes, the insurance premium is unrelated to the likelihood that the beneficiary will fall ill and benefits are provided on the basis of need.<ref>Ranson, M., 2002, ‘Reduction of Catastrophic Health Care Expenditures by a Community-Based Health Insurance Scheme in Gujarat, India: Current Experiences and Challenges’, Bulletin of the World Health Organization, vol. 80, no. 8</ref>
===Social assistance=== [[Social assistance]] schemes comprise programs designed to help the most [[social vulnerability|vulnerable individuals]] ( i.e., those with no other means of support such as single parent households, victims of natural disasters or civil conflict, handicapped people, or the destitute poor), households and communities to meet a [[Social floor]] and improve living standards. These programs consist of all forms of public action, government and non-government, that are designed to transfer resources, either cash or in-kind (e.g. food transfers), to eligible vulnerable and deprived persons.<ref>Howell, F., 2001, 'Social Assistance - Theoretical Background', in 'Social Protection in the Asia and Pacific', ed. I. Ortiz, Asian Development Bank, Manila, ch. 7</ref> Social assistance interventions may include: *'''[[Welfare]] and social services''' to highly vulnerable groups such as the physically or mentally disabled, orphans, or substance abusers. *'''Cash or in-kind transfers''' such as [[Ration stamp|food stamps]] and family allowances. *'''Temporary subsidies''' such as life-line tariffs, housing subsidies, or support of lower prices of staple food in times of crisis.<ref name="auto2">Asian Development Bank. Social Protection. [Date accessed October 31, 2010] (http://www.adb.org/SocialProtection/default.asp)</ref><ref name="auto2"/>
==Policy issues==
===Universalism vs. Targeting=== There are two main schools of thought concerning scope of social protection. Universalism argues that each person, by merit of simply being a citizen should be entitled to benefits from social protection programs. Such a policy would avoid [[means-testing]] and any conditionalities such as work requirements.<ref name="auto"/> One of the greatest benefits to this policy perspective is social solidarity, since everyone contributes collaboratively to a system that everyone also benefits from. [[Social security]] is one such example. Moreover, economists have argued that universalism is an investment in human capital that aids the development of a nation as a whole.<ref>Mares, I. 2007. “The economic consequences of the welfare state”. International Social Security Review, Vol. 60, No. 2/3.</ref> The [[World Bank]]'s 2019 [[World Development Report]] ''The Changing Nature of Work''<ref>[http://documents.worldbank.org/curated/en/816281518818814423/pdf/2019-WDR-Report.pdf World Bank World Development Report 2019: The Changing Nature of Work.]</ref> considers social protection from this perspective, describing existing schemes around the world and presenting simulation data on the potential costs. Opponents would argue that universalism is cost-ineffective and unfairly distorts individual efforts. Such an argument points toward targeting as a better solution.<ref name="auto3">Sen, Amartya. 1999. Development as Freedom. New York: Anchor Books.</ref> In such a case, the question arises of who should be the target population that receives benefits from social programs.
===Targeting income vs. capabilities=== Net income is the simplest method of determining a needy population. Some states use a [[Guaranteed Minimum Income]] system, in which all members of a state receive sufficient income to live on, so long as they meet certain conditions.<ref>“History of Basic Income”. Basic Income Earth Network. http://www.basicincome.org/bien/aboutbasicincome.html#history {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080621140909/http://www.basicincome.org/bien/aboutbasicincome.html |date=2008-06-21 }}.</ref> However, proponents of the [[capabilities approach]] argue that income is easier to misrepresent, and moreover, fails to target the root causal factors of poverty.<ref name="auto3"/> Hence, they recommend targeting a minimum level of basic capabilities that will impact [[quality of life]], such as institutional improvements like health and education. Policy examples might include a [[social floor]].<ref>ILO Social Protection Floors Recommendation No. 202 (2012) [http://www.ilo.org/dyn/normlex/en/f?p=NORMLEXPUB:12100:0::NO::P12100_INSTRUMENT_ID:3065524 ILO Recommendation No. 202]</ref>
===Means of provision=== Social protection is an expensive and difficult endeavor, by any means; the question remains how best to implement programs that effectively aid the people who need it the most. Currently, there are a number of mechanisms that provide social protection in various nations. These policies and instruments vary according to country context. In some nations, governments are strongly involved in the provision of social protection, following a [[developmentalism]] model, in which social protection is seen as a tool to promote economic growth. There are also nations which are characterized by dualism, in which there is state-provided protection for those who work in the formal sector, but little to no protection for those who work in the [[informal sector]]. Finally, there are nations in which the economy is largely agrarian, and a great majority of the population works in the informal economy. In those countries that have only residual social protection coverage and weak state capacity,social protection is mainly provided by non-governmental means such as kin, [[NGO]]s, and individual philanthropic donations.<ref name="auto"/>
==National programs==
===Developmentalism=== In [[South Korea]] and [[Taiwan]], the government provides extensive support for public programs, following the [[developmentalism]] model, in which social protection is seen as a tool to promote economic growth.<ref>Kwon, Huck-Ju. 2009. “The reform of the developmental welfare state in East Asia”. International Journal of Social Welfare. Volume 18, pages S12–S21, April 2009.</ref>
===Dualism=== In [[Argentina]], [[Brazil]], and [[South Africa]], there is a dualist structure of protected formal sector workers and marginalized informal sector workers.,<ref>Lo Vuolo, Barbeito. 1998. Models of stratification via pension policy. The case of Argentina. LASA Conference, Nov. 2004.</ref><ref>Ocampo, José Antonio. 2008. “The Latin American Economic Boom”Revista de Ciencia Política, Volume 28</ref>
===Agrarian-Informal=== In nations such as [[India]] and [[Tanzania]], governments struggle to provide adequate social protection, and citizens must instead depend on non-state actors and informal provisioning.
==Donor approaches== International donors and organizations have influenced social protection approaches both at the level of policy discourse and program design and implementation.<ref>See Brunori and O'Reilly (2011) for a review(http://mpra.ub.uni-muenchen.de/29495/)</ref> Even though The World Bank and International Labour Organization (ILO) are the major donors and the lead organizations in the field, other organizations are also concerned with social protection.<ref>Cook, S. and Kabeer, N., 2009, ‘Socio-economic Security over the Life Course: A Global Review of Social Protection’, Institute of Development Studies, Brighton(http://www.ids.ac.uk/publication/a-global-review-of-social-protection)</ref>
[[The World Bank]] is a source of financial and technical assistance for developing countries. In order to identify social risks and potential responses, The World Bank developed a tool called “[[Social Risk Management]]” (SRM). The SRM framework includes interventions that focus on managing risks before shocks occur. It is based on two assessments: (1) the poor are most exposed to diverse risks, and (2) the poor have the fewest tools to deal with these risks. The main elements of the SRM framework are: *''Risk reduction'' measures that focus on reducing risks in the labor market. *''Risk mitigation'' measures to deal with anticipated shock. *''Risk coping'' mechanisms to relieve the impact of risk after its occurred.<ref>The World Bank. Social Protection. [Date accessed October 31, 2010] (http://web.worldbank.org/WBSITE/EXTERNAL/TOPICS/EXTSOCIALPROTECTION/EXTLM/0,,contentMDK:20223809~menuPK:7109967~pagePK:148956~piPK:216618~theSitePK:390615,00.html</ref>
The [[Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development]] (OECD) brings 30 democratic countries together to seek answers to common problems and coordinate domestic and international policies. The [[Development Assistance Committee]] (DAC) of the OECD is responsible for the Poverty Network (POVNET) that has become very influential on policy development. The DAC-POVNET focuses on the following areas: *Poverty reduction *[http://www.oecd.org/document/1/0,3746,en_2649_34621_36573761_1_1_1_1,00.html Pro-poor growth] *People centered development *[[Decent work]] <ref>Organization for Economic and Co-Operation and Development. [Date accessed October 31, 2010] (http://www.oecd.org/pages/0,3417,en_36734052_36734103_1_1_1_1_1,00.html)</ref>
The [[International Labour Organization]], which covers both issues of social security and labor protection, has been the [[United Nations]] agency responsible for setting norms and standards at work. Currently the ILO focuses, amongst others, on the following strategies: *Extending social protection to all *Promoting decent working conditions *Providing programs for informal and migrant workers <ref>Cook, S. and Kabeer, N., 2009, ‘Socio-economic Security over the Life Course: A Global Review of Social Protection’, Institute of Development Studies, Brighton</ref>

{{other uses}} {{refimprove|date=July 2017}} In general, '''spectacle''' refers to an event that is memorable for the appearance it creates. Derived in [[Middle English]] from c. 1340 as "specially prepared or arranged display" it was borrowed from [[Old French]] ''spectacle'', itself a reflection of the [[Latin]] ''spectaculum'' "a show" from ''spectare'' "to view, watch" frequentative form of ''specere'' "to look at."<ref>[http://www.etymonline.com/index.php?search=spectacle&searchmode=none Online Etymological Dictionary]</ref> The word ''spectacle'' has also been a [[term of art]] in theater dating from the 17th century in English [[drama]]. ==The masque and spectacle== Court [[masque]]s and masques of the nobility were most popular in the [[James I of England|Jacobean]] and [[Charles I of England|Caroline]] era. Such masques, as their name implies, relied heavily upon a non-verbal theater. The character lists for masques would be quite small, in keeping with the ability of a small family of patrons to act, but the [[costume]]s and theatrical effects would be lavish. Reading the text of masques, such as ''The Masque at Ludlow'' (most often referred to as ''[[Comus (John Milton)|Comus]]''), the writing is spare, philosophical, and grandiose, with very few marks of traditional dramatic structure. This is partially due to the purpose of the masque being family entertainment and spectacle. Unlike ''The Masque at Ludlow'', most masques were recreations of well-known mythological or religious scenes. Some masques would derive from tableau. For example, [[Edmund Spenser]] (''Fairie Queene'' I, iv) describes a masque of ''The [[Seven Deadly Sins]]''.
Masques were [[multimedia]], for they almost always involved costuming and music as a method of conveying the story or narrative. [[Ben Jonson]], for example, wrote masques with the architect [[Inigo Jones]]. [[William Davenant]], who would become one of the major [[impresario]]s of the [[English Restoration]], also wrote pre-Revolutionary masques with Inigo Jones. The role of the architect was that of designer of the staging, which would be elaborate and often culminate in a [[fireworks]] show.
==The Hollywood spectacular== When the [[zoetrope]] and [[Nickelodeon (movie theater)|nickelodeon]] technology first appeared, the earliest films were spectacles. They caught the attention of common people. They showed things people would rarely see, and they showed it to the wide audience. * [[Thomas Edison]] filmed [[Eiffel Tower]], actual [[American Indians in the United States|American Indians]] in a simulated attack, and even celebrated [[beauty contest|beauty queens]]. * [[Louis Lumière]] filmed a train pulling into a station in 1895 (''[[L'Arrivée d'un train en gare de La Ciotat]]''). The camera was in front of the train, and the train "came" directly at the viewer. It astonished people unaccustomed to the illusion created by moving images.
==Spectacle and society== Within industrial and post-industrial cultural and state formations, '''spectacle''' has been appropriated to describe appearances that are purported to be simultaneously enticing, deceptive, distracting and superficial. ([[Jonathan Crary]]: 2005) Current academic theories of spectacle "highlight how the productive forces of marketing, often associated with media and Internet proliferation, create symbolic forms of practice that are emblematic of everyday situations"<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Thompson|first=Alex|last2=Stringfellow|first2=Lindsay|last3=Maclean|first3=Mairi|last4=MacLaren|first4=Andrew|last5=O’Gorman|first5=Kevin|date=2015-03-24|title=Puppets of necessity? Celebritisation in structured reality television|url=https://dx.doi.org/10.1080/0267257X.2014.988282|journal=Journal of Marketing Management|volume=31|issue=5-6|pages=478–501|doi=10.1080/0267257X.2014.988282|issn=0267-257X}}</ref>.
Spectacle can also refer to a society that critics describe as dominated by [[electronic media]], [[consumption (economics)|consumption]], and [[surveillance]], reducing citizens to spectators by political neutralization. Recently the word has been associated with the many ways in which a [[capitalist]] structure is purported to create play-like celebrations of its products and leisure time consumption. The work of French Marxist thinker [[Guy Debord]] is perhaps the best-known example of this critical analysis; see his ''[[The Society of the Spectacle]]'' (1967)
==See also== *[[Guy Debord]] *[[Entertainment]] *[[Extravaganza]] *[[Michel Foucault]] *[[Performance]] *''[[The Society of the Spectacle]]''

{{italic title}} {{Context|date=November 2009}} In a diagram from the book ''The Automated Society'',<ref> Bloomfield, Masse, ''The Automated Society'', Masefield Books, 1995.</ref> Bloomfield defines the history of humanity beginning over two million years ago and ending over a hundred thousand years in the future. The diagram is base on biological [[punctuated equilibrium]] and a parallel [[cultural evolution]]. The predictions of the [[future]] follow what has happened in the past.
The diagram of [[history]] shows humanity having long periods of stability interrupted with short periods of transition. Humanity is currently experiencing one of those short periods of transition, from a stable agricultural period going through a transitional [[industrial society]] leading to a stable automated period. [[Productivity]] is the key to the transition; when it is impossible to increase productivity, humanity will have arrived at the automated society.
Before humanity enters the automated society, we will suffer from two near term trends. One trend is the relentlessly increasing number of human beings. The second is the relentlessly decreasing number of jobs. Jobs will be eliminated by substituting men with machines. An example of this is agriculture where once in the peasant society there were ninety percent of the people working as farmers. With the introduction of tractors, only three percent of Americans work on the farm.
Once the problems of the lack of jobs, increased [[pollution]] and fewer natural resources are solved and the food factory put in operation, there should be a reconciliation of man to [[automation]]. In the automated society, men will live in affluence along with a total control of [[population]]. The one place where man will have an unlimited future will be in space. [[Space]] can provide for an unlimited increase in population and potentially the introduction of new human biological species.
== See also == * [[Accelerating change]] * [[Automation]] * [[Productivity]] * [[Punctuated equilibrium]] * [[Sociocultural Evolution]] * ''[[Mankind in Transition]]''

'''USPID''' (''Unione Scienziati per il Disarmo'' in [[Italian language|Italian]]) is the '''Italian Union of Scientists for Disarmament''', an association established in 1982 with the purpose of providing information about and analysis of arms control and [[disarmament]].
Members of USPID believe that this task is part of the social responsibility of scientists.
The issues addressed by USPID include [[nuclear weapon|nuclear arms]]-control and disarmament, nuclear proliferation, consequences of nuclear explosions, control of fissile material, developments of military technology, conventional disarmament, chemical and biological disarmament, problems of conflicts and conflict resolution.
Members of USPID, both individually and collectively, share their views with Italian policy-makers and opinion-makers.
USPID organizes conferences and meetings, including the biennial Castiglioncello conference (now at its 11th edition), courses and seminars in Italian Universities, courses for high-school teachers.
USPID promotes the establishment of inter-departmental Centers affiliated to Italian Universities, and has actively collaborated for many years with the CIRP-UniBa (Centro Interdipartimentale di Ricerche sulla Pace, [[University of Bari]]).<ref>{{cite web | title = Centro Interdipartimentale di Ricerche sulla Pace | publisher = [[University of Bari]] | accessdate = 2009-05-20 | url = http://www.peace.uniba.it/ }} Universita' di Bari</ref>
USPID collaborates with international organizations of scientists and other Italian institutions, such as Archivio Disarmo (Roma), Forum per i Problemi della Pace e della Guerra (Firenze). Members of USPID participate in [[Pugwash Conferences on Science and World Affairs|Pugwash]] and ISODARCO meetings.<ref>{{cite web | title = ISODARCO - Main Page | accessdate = 2009-05-20 | url = http://www.isodarco.it/ }}</ref>
In 1995 USPID began a standing collaboration with Landau Network-Centro Volta, Como (Italy).<ref>{{cite web|title=Centro Landau |accessdate=2009-05-20 |url=http://lxmi.mi.infn.it/~landnet/landau.html |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090327215408/http://lxmi.mi.infn.it/~landnet/landau.html |archivedate=March 27, 2009 }}</ref> This institution organizes, together with [[UNESCO]] and under the sponsorship of the Italian Ministry of Foreign Affairs, conferences and research projects on different topics, including disarmament, non-proliferation and scientific-technological aspects of International Security.
